_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This plan summarizes the Risk Management Program (RMP) developed and implemented at the ACH Food Companies, Inc facility located at 3001 Highway 45 W. Bypass in Humboldt, TN.  In compliance with applicable Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requirements, the ACH Food Companies, Inc. Risk Management Program document, which is sumarized by this plan, describes the following components of a RMP:

   -  A hazard assesment program that identifies and analyzes the potential on-siteand off-site impact of a worst-case alternate release scenarios of regulated substances, and includes documentation of five year accident histories involving regulated substances.

   -  An accidential release prevention program that covers operating procedures, maintenance, mechanical intergity, training, management of change, process safety information, and other similar information involving ammonia.

   -  An emergency action plan to mitigate any accidential releases that occur.

   -  An overall system to manage the development and implementation of a risk management system.

The plan is submitted in accordance with applicable regulations for the on-site refrigeration process covered by RMP regulations.

The subject ACH facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia (CAS No. 7664-41-7) as a refrigerant to maintain the proper temperature in food manfacturing operations.

The refrigeration process uses anhydrous ammonia at a stationary source in amounts greater than the RMP threshold of 10,000 pounds and a catastropic release of this substance could impact public receptors.  Therefore, the subject facility is regulated by Program 3 requirements.

There have been no reportable accidents involving ammonia within the past 5 years.

The facility has performed a worst case release scenario which estimates a potential loss of eight thousand pounds of ammonia which could potentially travel up to one-half mile.  In the alternative, the facility has evaluated a five hundred pound release which could travel up

to one-tenth of a mile.

ACH's Emergency Response Program was developed in compliance with RMP regulatory requirements cited in 40 CFR 68.90 (b) (1) and (3), and the subject is a non-responding facility.

The ACH Ammonia Emergency Response Program limits employees to actions to end small leaks or releases (e.g. shutting a valve), mitigating a release that does not pose an immediate safety or health hazard, and other similar actions to minor incidents that are considered incidental responces.  Emergency actions for the subject ACH facility have been coordinated with the local fire department and the local emergency planning commision.

The ACH Risk Management Program will be revised as necessary to ensure compliance with applicable RMP regulations and to improve safety.
